container-title: and online The Catholic Encyclopedia. More technical, but not all in German, is the still incomplete Reallexikon der Assyriologie
The Oxford Encyclopedia of Archaeology in the Near East
title: Jack Sasson’s four-volume Civilizations of the Ancient Near East

is a helpful place to start, and it has a great index. And for Israel don’t forget the many dictionaries of the Bible, especially Katharine Doob Sakenfeld, editor, New Interpreter’s Dictionary of the Bible
For archaeology Eric Meyers
is helpful and has articles ranging more broadly than its title might indicate

container-title: and the Oxford Companion to Cuneiform Cultures
title: My A Companion to the Ancient Near East
has articles on many topics, as do the Oxford Companion to Ancient Anatolia

container-title: The Ancient Near East: Historical Sources in Translation
STIMULATING STUDIES Difficult but still worth reading is A. Leo Oppenheim’s Ancient Mesopotamia
note: an opinionated and erudite introduction. I have found John Wilson’s eloquent The Culture of Ancient
title: ANTHOLOGIES The old standby is James Pritchard’s Ancient Near Eastern Texts
which still has a wider range of translations than more recent anthologies. A competitor might be the three-volume The Context of Scripture
but it is very expensive
Benjamin Foster’s Before the Muses: An Anthology of Akkadian Literature
translates the memorable pieces of literature in Akkadian only, and Jeremy Black’s The Literature of Ancient Sumer
does the same for Sumerian. For Egyptian William Kelly Simpson’s Literature of Ancient Egypt
translates the major pieces, and Miriam Lichtheim’s three-volume collection Ancient Egyptian Literature
1980, is worth consulting. The Society of Biblical Literature has an active list of small volumes of translations of texts from particular periods which can be very helpful

and his collaborators have translated the Mesopotamian royal inscriptions from many periods. Online resources include the CDLI, < cdli.ucla.edu >, the Cuneiform Data Library Information site run by the University of California at Los Angeles for economic texts, and Oxford’s Sumerian Literature Project, < etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk >; the sites are frequently updated and so can give the most recent insights in translation

note: translated as The Mind of Egypt, New York: Metropolitan, 2002, German: 1996.
title: to be helpful. For religion for both of the major cultures Henri Frankfort’s Kingship and the Gods is very clear
From later times Wolfram von Soden’s The Ancient Orient
German: 1992, sums up the views of the leading Assyriologist of Germany. I have found the various studies of Jan Assmann to be very engaging, especially his intellectual history of Egypt

note: It is too early to say if the same will be said of my 2011 book Religions of the Ancient Near East, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
title: Among textbook introductions Ian Shaw’s Oxford History of Ancient Egypt
is both beautiful and well informed. More recent is Salima Ikram’s Ancient Egypt
with her own marvelous pictures from her scampering all over the country. Some people have found my 1997 Life in the Ancient Near East, New Haven, CT and
to be a helpful beginning at understanding social and economic life

container-title: Journal of the American Oriental Society
note: and compare his valuable study on Edward Hincks in The Edward Hincks Bicentenary Lectures,
title: Arrest and Movement: Space and Time in the Art of the Ancient Near East
recapitulates the arguments about coins. Daniel Fleming, Democracy’s Ancient Ancestors: Mari and Early Collective Governance
brings together the evidence for governing councils
Encounter With the Divine in Mesopotamia and Israel
is a ground-breaking comparison sympathetic to both elements. Peter Daniels has described what you need for decipherment, “‘Shewing of Hard Sentences and Dissolving of Doubts’: The First Decipherment
On the contrast between the French and the English ways of publicizing their discoveries see
Inventing Assyria: Exoticism and Reception in Nineteenth-century England and France
The reference to the House of David is in the Inscription from Tell Dan in northern
An Aramaic Stele Fragment from Tel Dan

note: sketches the political history. For birth rituals see Gary Beckman, Hittite Birth Rituals,
title: essay was translated by Benjamin Foster, “The Conceptual Autonomy of the Mesopotamian World
On deciphering Egyptian see Lesley and Roy Adkins, The Keys of Egypt: The Obsession to Decipher Egyptian Hieroglyphics
On modern Egyptian study of ancient Egypt, see Donald Malcolm Reid, Whose Pharaohs? Archaeology, Museums, and Egyptian National Identity from Napoleon to World War I
Trevor Bryce, The Kingdom of the Hittites

container-title: Marc Bloch explored the myth of origins in his The Historian’s Craft
title: For Johan Huizinga’s definition of history see his essay
